questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a generalised rash with oral mucosal involvement. On examination , multiple erythematous macules and target lesions over the body are seen and oral mucosa shows hemorrhagic crusts, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythema Multiforme The given clinical picture is suggestive of Erythema Multiforme. Erythema Multiforme is a reactive erythema characterised by target lesions and involvement of oral mucosa. It is often caused by infections or due to drug intake.

Highyeild:

Erythema multiforme: Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis Cause: Most common cause: Infection - HSV-1, Mycoplasma pneumoniae Drugs: NSAIDs, Antimalarial, sulphonamides Connective tissue diseases: SLE Leukaemia and certain internal malignancy Features: Target lesions with 3 zones Site: Palms and soles Symmetrical Photo aggravation of the lesions often occurs Treatment: Treat the underlying cause, steroids Central zone: Dusky- Papule, vesicle or bulla Intermediate zone: Edematous ring Peripheral: Erythematous border

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Erythema nodosum: These are that are seen in particular infections, pregnancy and autoimmune conditions Option C. Erythema migrans: Bull’s eye lesions seen in Lyme disease.an expanding red patch of skin that starts at the site of a tick bite and gradually expands to reach several dozens of centimetres in size. Option D. Erythema annulare centrifugum: It is a chronic reactive form of annular erythema with erythematous, circular, arciform, and polycyclic lesions, with a characteristic delicate scale called ‘trailing scale’. It is caused by hypersensitivity to cutaneous fungal infection and endocrine disorder.

Extraedge:

Types of Erythema

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient on NSAIDs presents with solitary violaceous plaque over lips since 8 hrs. He gives a history of similar lesions on intake of NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fixed drug eruption The given clinical scenario suggests Fixed drug eruption. It is a cutaneous adverse drug reaction characterised by recurrent well-defined lesions occurring in the same sites each time the offending drug is taken.

Highyeild:

Fixed drug reaction It is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction (delayed type) Sites: Mucosa (most common) Trunk Extremities Drugs responsible: NSAIDS Cotrimoxazole Tetracyclines Carbamazepine Metronidazole Characteristics: Fixed location of drug reaction, due to memory-T cells formed after 1st exposure. On first-time intake, a reaction occurs after 10 days, but with re-exposure, a reaction occurs within 30 mins to 8 hours of drug intake. The lesions are violaceous plaques with peripheral erythema Recurs at the same site Heels with hyperpigmentation Treatment: Stop the offending drug Topical corticosteroids

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Serum sickness: It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction to certain medications, injected proteins used to treat immune conditions, or antiserum characterised by fever, erythema, itching and rash. Option C. Viral illness: Rashes caused by viral illness are often generalised. Option D. Erythema Multiforme: It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction caused by bacterial or viral infections or specific drug intakes characterised by macules, Papules, and vesicles that typically progress to target lesions

questions.text: Drugs causing acanthosis nigricans are all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Minocycline Acanthosis nigricans is a condition characterised by brown to gray black papillomatous cutaneous thickening in flexural areas. Drugs causing acanthosis nigricans: Corticosteroids Nicotinic acid Diethylstilbestrol Fusiliers acid Aripirazole Minocycline is associated with blue-grey pigmentation in the skin , nails, bulbar conjunctiva, oral mucosa after long term therapy and not associated with Acanthosis nigricans.

Highyeild:

Acanthosis Nigricans: Velvety papillomatous overgrowth of the epidermis that presents as dark and thick skin in the flexural areas. Cause: Obesity Diabetes Metabolic syndrome Internal malignancy Drugs: Nicotinic acid, DES, oral corticosteroids Autoimmune diseases: SLE Features: Symmetric, thickened, brown, velvety patches and plaques of skin that appear: Most commonly in the intertriginous areas: axillae, groin, and back of the neck Treat underlying conditions.

questions.text: What percentage of a patient’s body surface area would need to show sloughing to make a diagnosis of Toxic epidermal necrolysis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

>30% TEN is a rare, potentially fatal , adverse drug reaction characterised by tenderness and erythema of the skin and mucosa, and extensive mucocutaneous exfoliation covering >30% Body surface area.

Highyeild:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis It is a severe mucocutaneous reaction characterised by necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. Cause: Drugs Antiepileptics: Lamotrigine, phenytoin, phenobarbital and carbamazepine Anti-inflammatory: Piroxicam Anti-retroviral: Nevirapine, abacavir Sulfa antibiotics Pathogenesis: CD8 and NK cell-mediated keratinocyte death Features: Atypical target lesions (2 zones only) Can also present as multiple bullous lesions or diffuse erythema Fever, arthralgia, myalgia may be present

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to severe blistering on his face for 2 days, as shown. He has a history of epilepsy and was started on a new seizure medication 1 week ago. This new medication blocks sodium channels. Physical examination reveals lesions of the genital, nasal, and oral mucosa and the face. Which drugs were most likely prescribed to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lamotrigine The given scenario and picture with the patient with extensive shedding of the epidermis and blistering of the nasal, oral, and genital mucosae is suggestive of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Antiepileptics causing SJS include Lamotrigine, phenytoin, phenobarbital and carbamazepine . Among the options, lamotrigine is the only answer choice.

Highyeild:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis It is a severe mucocutaneous reaction characterised by necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. Cause: Drugs Antiepileptics: Lamotrigine, phenytoin, phenobarbital and carbamazepine Anti-inflammatory: Piroxicam Anti-retroviral: Nevirapine, abacavir Sulfa antibiotics Pathogenesis: CD8 and NK cell-mediated keratinocyte death Features: Atypical target lesions (2 zones only) Can also present as multiple bullous lesions or diffuse erythema Fever, arthralgia, myalgia may be present

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A.,B.,D. : Ethosuximide, Gabapentin, Lorazepam do not cause Steven Johnson syndrome.
